dc:description: NSUN2 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive RASopathies in 2012 (Martinez et al., PMID 22577224). At least 2 variants (e.g. frameshift, splice site) have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data, and experimental data but only the mouse model supporting this association could be scored (PMIDs: 24102521, 22144916, 22577224). Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 2 probands in 2 publications (PMIDs 22577224, 24102521). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 2 additional family members. This gene-disease association is supported by a mouse model indicating that homozygous deletion of the NSUN2 gene caused short stature and craniofacial anomalies (PMIDs: 22144916). However, the patients reported with NSUN2 variants did not possess convincing clinical features consistent with Noonan syndrome, despite the reports from Fahiminiya et al. 2014 suggesting that the condition was Noonan-like. Therefore, using the expert judgment of the ClinGen RASopathy Gene Curation Expert Panel these cases were not scored. In summary,  the relationship between NSUN2 and autosomal recessive RASopathies is disputed. More evidence is needed to either support or refute the role NSUN2 plays in this disease. Additionally, this gene will be separately assessed by the ClinGen ID/Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel for complex neurodevelopmental disorder. This classification was approved by the ClinGen RASopathy Gene Curation Expert Panel on 2/4/2019 (SOP Version 5).
curationReasonDescription: The patients reported with NSUN2 variants did not possess convincing clinical features consistent with Noonan syndrome, despite the reports from Fahiminiya et al. 2014 suggesting that the condition was Noonan-like. Therefore, using the expert judgment of the ClinGen RASopathy Gene Curation Expert Panel these cases were not scored.

evidence.dc:description: Patients in this family display some features of a RASopathy and were described by Fahiminiya 2014 as Noonan like, however the features that have been described are not sufficient to classify these patients as Noonan syndrome especially because this paper asserted taht they were Dubowitz like first. Therefore cases were not scored.

evidence.rdfs:label: Martinez Family 1455 proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Dubowitz-like syndrome:  small stature,  intellectual disability  mild microcephaly  distinct facial appearance (blepharophimosis, broad nasal bridge, hypertelorism, smooth philtrum, downturning upper lip, sloping forehead and micrognathia, eczema.  By 1 year of age, growth retardation and developmental delay were noted.  Brain MRI unremarkable.  **hoarse voice, triangular face, round nose tip and abnormal ears were NOT reported but are occasionally observed in DS so this was called Dubowitz-like

evidence.dc:description: This family is described to be Noonan-like but the features described do not provide enough evidence for experts to score this case towards NSUN2's association with any RASopathies.

evidence.rdfs:label: Fahiminiya Family 2: Noonan-like syndrome
evidence.detectionMethod: NSUN2 sequencing was conducted after negative sequencing in PTPN11, BRAF, HRAS, KRAS, MAPK1, MAPK2, SHOC2, RAF1 and SOS1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: bilateral ptosis, hypotonia, and facial features suggestive of Zellweger syndrome. However, plasma very-long-chain fatty acid, phytanic acid, pristanic acid, and pipecolic acid concentrations were within normal levels. age of 6 months, he presented with developmental delay and facial features reminiscent of Noonan syndrome.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Sequencing of genes in RAS/MAPK pathway (PTPN11, BRAF, HRAS, KRAS, MAPK1, MAPK2, SHOC2, RAF1 and SOS1

evidence.rdfs:label: Fahiminiya Family 2: Noonan-like syndrome

evidence.dc:description: Did not score because proband will not be scored.

evidence.dc:description:
Short stature and craniofacial anomalies could be indicative of a NS phenotype but is barely specific to RASopathies
Of note, no claim was made in this paper but Fahiminya made the claim that this was a model for NS.

Will be counted on the ID/Autism curation
These mice displayed some clinical features of NS
evidence.rdfs:label: Knockout mouse model (heterozygous and homozygous)
